caption: Table 1: Accuracy and privacy metrics. DeBERTa XXLarge.
description: This table presents the results of experiments conducted using the DeBERTa XXLarge model. It compares the accuracy and privacy metrics of three different fine-tuning methods: one without LoRA adapters, one with regular LoRA fine-tuning, and one using the proposed P3EFT method. The metrics include accuracy on three datasets (SST2, QNLI, and MNLI) and three privacy leakage measures (Spectral attack AUC, Norm attack AUC, and K-means accuracy). The table shows that P3EFT achieves comparable accuracy to regular LoRA fine-tuning while offering significantly better privacy protection.

caption: Table 1: Accuracy and privacy metrics. DeBERTa XXLarge.
description: This table presents the results of experiments conducted using the DeBERTa XXLarge model.  It compares the accuracy and privacy metrics (leakage) of three different methods: training without LoRAs, regular fine-tuning with LoRAs, and the proposed P3EFT method.  The metrics are shown for three datasets: SST2, QNLI, and MNLI. Leakage values represent the vulnerability of the methods to privacy attacks, with lower values indicating better privacy.

caption: Table 3: Accuracy and privacy metrics for LLaMA-2 7B.
description: This table presents the accuracy and privacy metrics for fine-tuning the LLaMA-2 7B model using different methods on the SST2 and QNLI datasets.  The metrics include accuracy (acc) and a privacy leakage score (leak).  The methods compared are: training without LoRAs, regular fine-tuning with LoRAs, the Distance Correlation (DC) defense method, and the proposed P³EFT method.  The privacy leakage score is a composite measure reflecting vulnerability to several privacy attacks.

caption: Table 4: Regularization parameter α for the P³EFT method. The values in the table represent powers of the 10.
description: This table shows the hyperparameter α used for the P³EFT method across different models and datasets.  The hyperparameter α controls the balance between the main task loss and a regularization term in the loss function.  The values listed are exponents of 10, indicating the magnitude of the regularization strength.

caption: Table 5: Regularization parameter α for the DC method. The values in the table represent powers of the 10⁻¹
description: This table shows the regularization parameter α used for the Distance Correlation (DC) method in the paper's experiments. The parameter α controls the trade-off between the main task loss and the regularizer.  The values listed are powers of 10⁻¹, indicating the magnitude of the regularization strength.  Separate values are provided for each model and dataset.
